titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Peace and Social Justice Program (PSJ), Vice President, Office Files of Mary E. McClymont
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Peace and Social Justice Program (PSJ), Vice President, Office Files of Mary E. McClymont FA594
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Brian Bleich and Nancy Ng Tam, The Winthrop Group

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-11-19 00:39:39 -0500.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Peace and Social Justice Program (PSJ), Vice President, Office Files of Mary E. McClymont
did.abstract: Ms. McClymont started as a Program Officer with the Foundation's Human Rights and Governance Program in April of 1988. She was made Deputy Director of the Rights and Social Justice Program in October of 1993. After serving as Acting Director from August 1995 to May of 1996, she was subsequently promoted to Senior Director of the Rights and Social Justice program, later Peace and Social Justice. While at the Ford Foundation, Ms. McClymont led a team of researchers who documented NGO law-related strategies to advance human rights globally. This work resulted in the publication of Many Roads to Justice: The Law-Related Work of Ford Foundation Grantees Around the World (2000). She left the Foundation in 2000, but returned from 2006 to 2008 to serve as Vice President of the program. The office files of Mary E. McClymont span from 1969 to 2008, with the bulk of the records date from 1981 to 2008. The files contain extensive information about the Global Law Programs Learning Initiative (GLPLI). The Initiative documented and studied the Foundation's work in promoting legal reform, public interest law and access to justice from 1998 to 2001. Another project heavily documented in the collection is the Comparative Constitutionalism Project. Other files pertain to grantees or Foundation policy. The files related to the Learning Enhancements Fund are particularly illustrative in regards to Foundation policy. They document the internal Foundation process behind how grant assessments were made, and include a practical guide for program staff files.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

bioghist.head: Organizational History
bioghist.p: When Susan Berresford became President of the Foundation in 1996, she established a new program structure consisting of three large thematic programs. Peace and Social Justice (PSJ) was one of these three programs. Its overall mission was to help improve government performance and accountability, foster a thriving independent civil society, and promote human rights. It was comprised of two global units: Governance and Civil Society, and Human Rights. In 2009, Peace and Social Justice became the Democracy, Rights and Justice Program.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Mary E. McClymont received a B.A. from the University of Nebraska at Lincoln in 1971, a J.D. from Georgetown University Law Center in 1976, and an LL.M. in International Legal Studies from American University's Washington College of Law in 1987.

Ms. McClymont started as a Program Officer with the Foundation's Human Rights and Governance Program in April of 1988. She was made Deputy Director of the Rights and Social Justice Program in October of 1993. After serving as Acting Director from August 1995 to May of 1996, she was subsequently promoted to Senior Director of the Rights and Social Justice program. In October 1996, Rights and Social Justice became Peace and Social Justice.

While at the Ford Foundation, Ms. McClymont led a team of researchers who documented NGO law-related strategies to advance human rights globally. This work resulted in the publication of Many Roads to Justice: The Law-Related Work of Ford Foundation Grantees Around the World (2000). She left the Foundation in December of 2000, but returned from 2006 to 2008 to serve as the Vice President of Peace and Social Justice. After leaving, she was appointed Executive Director of Global Rights, a human rights organization. As of 2011 she is President of the Public Welfare Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The office files of Mary E. McClymont span from 1969 to 2008, with the bulk of the records date from 1981 to 2008. The files contain extensive information about the Global Law Programs Learning Initiative (GLPLI). The Initiative studied and documented the Foundation's work in the legal field to promote legal reform, public interest law and access to justice from 1998 to 2001. According to a 1998 memorandum, the purpose of the project was to review past and current Foundation grants in order to guide future programming. The end result was the book, Many Roads to Justice. The book was translated into several languages and distributed to nonprofit organizations around the globe.

The collection also contains information about the Comparative Constitutionalism Project. Developed and administered by the Governance unit of Peace and Social Justice, the project studied alternative political arrangements for promoting pluralism in diverse societies. Constitutionalism in Africa (1999-2000) was a focus, as the Foundation's goal was to encourage ethnic harmony without forcing homogenization on autonomous cultures and communities.

Other files pertain to grantees or Foundation policy. The files related to the Learning Enhancements Fund are particularly illustrative in regards to Foundation policy. They document the internal Foundation process behind how grant assessments were made, and include a practical guide for program staff files.

processinfo.head: Processing Information Note
processinfo.p: The original volume of 14 cubic feet accessioned by the Ford Foundation Archives in 2011 was reduced during processing to 6.3 cubic feet.
Duplicates, reference files, grant proposals, and files that addressed purely financial matters were not retained.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Collections
relatedmaterial.p: FA674 Ford Foundation records, Peace and Social Justice (PSJ), Office Files of Mary McClymont, 1984-1990.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Appendix A: Reports â€“ Unpublished reports written by Ford Foundation staff and consultants were removed from their original folders, scanned and transferred to the Archives' collection of staff and consultant reports. See Appendix A for a list of these reports and their specific assigned number. The reports are listed in alphabetical order by author. The assigned number may be used to access reports in the online catalog.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Completion of a use agreement is required prior to providing scholarly access. See RAC Head of Reference (or applicable designee) for details. Ford Foundation holds title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them. The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection for scholarly purposes. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records more than 10 years old are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

did.unittitle: Board of Trustees

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files contain dockets for meetings of the Board of Trustees. Several of the files also contain handwritten notes, memoranda or discussion papers relating to meetings of the Board or the Board's Audit and Management Committee.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Date spans of this series range from 1981-2008. As such, some of the material is closed to scholarly access until the applicable records are more than ten years old. Material will be open for research as records reach the ten year threshold, 2018-2019.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ms. McClymont kept subject files on grantees and grant projects, Ford Foundation policy, and areas where Foundation policy directly impacted grant projects, such as Foundation support for affirmative action.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains reports by consultants and Ford program staff. A number of the reports were created before Ms. McClymont joined the Foundation in 1988. Topics include legal reform and human rights work in Latin America. A few reports pertain to democratization and human rights in Chile. Other reports discuss legal reform in Vietnam, citizenship in Brazil, and university law clinics in South America. This series also holds several reports on trips to Sri Lanka, Latin America, and Russia, the Czech Republic and Poland.
